@SandrewFinance @felixsalmon @ranjanxroy no if 0.1 shares of AAPL moves against you by 100% you lose $13. you're not dead. no market maker is ever going to blow up from selling a fractional share at the wrong price.

@SandrewFinance @ranjanxroy @felixsalmon but there are various flavors of retail, and the flavor that is like "buys 0.1 shares of AAPL" is particularly harmless; that person is just not going to move the price at all. so if you sell AAPL to that person at $136.40, you collect the half-spread with very little risk.

@SandrewFinance @ranjanxroy @felixsalmon the market makers/wholesalers who fill RH's orders are in the business of buying at the bid and selling at the offer. if AAPL trades at $136.37/$136.40, the MMs bid to buy it at $136.37 and offer to sell it at $136.40.

@felixsalmon in general these stats seem to be much lower for weird small stocks than for S&P 500s so maybe it does make sense for RH to be worse: if a lot of people are buying 1,000 shares of $0.10 stocks maybe they're getting a lot of non-nbbo fills.

@danprimack @felixsalmon like in a direct listing, there is no "IPO price," there is only the opening price on the exchange, and early investors can sell then. with Google, as with every IPO, there was an IPO price, and then the next day there was an entirely separate opening auction.
